unnormalised: What does IMD mean in weather forecasts?
normalised: What does I-M-D mean in weather forecasts?

unnormalised: IMD stands for the India Meteorological Department. It's the main agency responsible for meteorological observations, weather forecasting, and seismology in India. They provide crucial info about weather conditions, rainfall, temperature fluctuations etc., often broadcasting updates at 8:30 AM and 5:30 PM. These updates are extremely important for farmers, fishermen, and really anyone planning outdoor activities. You'll often see them cited in news reports using phrases like "as per IMD reports..."
normalised: I-M-D stands for the India Meteorological Department. It is the main agency responsible for meteorological observations, weather forecasting, and seismology in India. They provide crucial info about weather conditions, rainfall, temperature fluctuations et cetera, often broadcasting updates at eight thirty A-M and five thirty P-M. These updates are extremely important for farmers, fishermen, and really anyone planning outdoor activities. You will often see them cited in news reports using phrases like "as per I-M-D reports..."

unnormalised: The IMD uses various sources to gather its data. Things like satellite imagery, weather stations across the country, and sophisticated radar systems. They then use complex models to predict future weather patterns. Their forecasts range from short-term (e.g., next 24 hrs) to medium-range (3-7 days) and even seasonal forecasts. Keep an eye out, especially during the monsoon season (usually June to September), when IMD warnings are vital for disaster preparedness.
normalised: The I-M-D uses various sources to gather its data. Things like satellite imagery, weather stations across the country, and sophisticated radar systems. They then use complex models to predict future weather patterns. Their forecasts range from short-term (e.g., next twenty four hours) to medium-range (three to seven days) and even seasonal forecasts. Keep an eye out, especially during the monsoon season (usually June to September), when I-M-D warnings are vital for disaster preparedness.

unnormalised: Understanding IMD's announcements can help you plan your days and stay safe during extreme weather. So, next time you hear "IMD forecasts heavy rainfall on 15/07/2024 in Mumbai," you know it’s coming from the reliable source of the India Meteorological Department. Knowing that the forecast predicts a high of 38°C on 20/04/2024 in Delhi can help you decide to stay indoors during the hottest part of the day. Be informed, be prepared!
normalised: Understanding I-M-D's announcements can help you plan your days and stay safe during extreme weather. So, next time you hear "I-M-D forecasts heavy rainfall on fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four in Mumbai," you know it is coming from the reliable source of the India Meteorological Department. Knowing that the forecast predicts a high of thirty eight degree celsius on twentieth April two thousand and twenty four in Delhi can help you decide to stay indoors during the hottest part of the day. Be informed, be prepared!
